document_title: Acute appendicitis: Causes, signs and prevention
subsection_content:
Acute appendicitis is a condition of bacterial infection in the lumen of the appendix, which can be caused by: Hyperplasia of the appendix, fecal stones, parasites (roundworms burrowing into the appendix), foreign objects (fruit seeds). )… This is a medical emergency and needs to be treated promptly to avoid dangerous complications. If inflammation persists, the infection can spread into the abdominal cavity - the area of ​​the body containing the liver, pancreas, intestines... seriously threatening life. Accordingly, the optimal treatment method is to use antibiotics combined with surgical excision.
Acute appendicitis can occur at any age but is most common between 10 and 20 years old. Among them, men predominate, with a male/female ratio of 1.4:1.
Acute appendicitis is caused by an infectious agent
